Comment: Can they survive without federal government aid?  I think they can, and will, survive. Changes in the business model will be inevitable, though - as universities will have to extract vastly higher payments from businesses (Pharma, Electronics, medicine, military) for the research which they've hitherto been sponging off of as long as the government has been funding applied and basic research. They (businesses) were able to do this since the government funding was ostensibly targeted toward "the public good," allowing business to profit off of those activities, often at no cost to themselves other than to hire the graduates who made the research possible. Now, presuming trump's disdain for education and research continues to fester, the businesses will have to pay full costs, and will lock the discoveries they will have paid for - to keep the resulting profits within their commercial bubbles - never to escape into the "public good."  I'm quite sure this is exactly what MAGA means by GREAT.

Comment: That is a gross oversimplification of what is going on.  Harvard didn't choose to create an endowment to become a hedge fund corporation. Poeple donated money, the principle is invested and the returns are used to provide scholarships and fund operations.  If you give an insitution $100 dollars, they could spend the $100 on paper one time or invest it and use the returns to buy paper in perpetuity.  This funding model has grown in popularity because of the state and federal government's decreasing investment in higher education. Donor's are encouraged to agree to an investment endowment instead fo straight cash for a specific purpose for this very reason. The money goes much farter, much longer.
